Keywords: man, comes, office, preoperative, evaluation, adrenalectomy, scheduled, 2, weeks, One, month, care, emergency department, pain, right flank, motor vehicle collision, blood pressure, 160/100, mm Hg and CT scan, abdomen, incidental, left adrenal mass, laboratory studies, complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, liver function tests, reference ranges, patient, healthy, elevated blood pressure, no medications, follow-up visit, office 2, weeks, disclosed, elevated, urinary normetanephrine, metanephrine, plasma, concentrations, patient, surgeon, recommended, adrenalectomy, vital signs, temperature, 36.6, 97.9, pulse, 100/min, 14/min, blood pressure, 170/95, Physical examination, no significant, findings, preoperative, preparation, treatment

Question Keywords: male, marathon runner, office, complaint, right-sided rib pain, Physical examination, normal heart, lung findings, exhalation, dysfunction, ribs 4-5, right, muscles, muscle groups, dysfunction, direct method
Answer Choice: (a) anterior scalene (b) latissimus dorsi (c) pectoralis minor (d) quadratus lumborum
Context: The heart and lung findings were normal in the physical examination. On exhalation, there was dysfunction in the ribs 4-5 on the right. The most associated answer choice with the given keywords is (c) pectoralis minor which originates from the outer surfaces of the 3rd to 5th ribs.

Question Keywords: male, office, low back pain, denies, any, trauma, says, truck, day, job, Examination, patient, prone position, deep sacral, left, posterior inferior lateral angle, right, lumbosacral junction, springs, freely, compression, diagnosis
Answer Choice: (a) left-on-left sacral torsion (b) left-on-right sacral torsion (c) right unilateral sacral flexion (d) right-on-right sacral torsion 
Context: The physical examination revealed a deep sacral sulcus on the left, a posterior inferior lateral angle on the right, and freely compressible springs at the lumbosacral junction.  Based on these findings, the most likely answer choice is (d) right-on-right sacral torsion.
